<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fpublic%20and%20social%20sector%2Four%20insights%2Fhow%20us%20states%20can%20advance%20a%20successful%20clean%20energy%20transition%2Fhow-us-states-can-advance-a-successful-clean-energy-transition.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="how-us-states-can-advance-a-successful-clean-energy-transition" data-layer-report-name="how-us-states-can-advance-a-successful-clean-energy-transition>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (11 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>As the United States </strong>moves toward decarbonization, states and their leaders will help determine whether net zero is achievedand whether the energy transition elevates communities to deliver a more prosperous future for all. Last year, we outlined <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/toward-a-more-orderly-us-energy-transition-six-key-action-areas">six critical action areas</a> that could enable a more orderly transition, from designing a capital-efficient and affordable energy system to accelerating technological innovation to ensure timely deployment of new clean technologies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="11c38236-842a-4cf2-baf1-4524a0843bd4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="11c38236-842a-4cf2-baf1-4524a0843bd4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more, see <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/toward-a-more-orderly-us-energy-transition-six-key-action-areas">Toward a more orderly US energy transition: Six key action areas</a>, McKinsey, January 12, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Across these areas, states have an opportunity to advance the transition, improve energy affordability, and support inclusive economic growth. Traditionally, states have influenced the creation of new sources of energy through formal policies, regulatory constructs, and planning and permitting authorities. But the national energy landscape is undergoing tectonic shifts. </p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>How the Inflation Reduction Act could unlock new net-zero opportunities for state agencies</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA)</strong> directs nearly $400 billion in federal funding to clean energy. It could boost the net-zero transition at the state and local levels in a few key ways: </p>
<ul>
    <li>accelerating the deployment and commercialization of clean-energy technologies (hydrogen; long-duration energy storage; and carbon capture, utilization, and storage, for example) by making it more cost-effective to scale and deploy them</li>
    <li>improving affordability and access to clean energy, energy efficiency, and electrification for states, municipalities, and tribal governments through tax incentives, grants, loans, and competitive financing through the creation of a single, national green bank</li>
    <li>stimulating local economic and workforce development by facilitating domestic manufacturing and clean procurement and supporting workforce training programs</li>
    <li>building climate resiliency and advancing equity through investments in resilience and conservation solutions for rural, remote, tribal, low-income, and climate-vulnerable communities</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>McKinsey <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/navigating-americas-net-zero-frontier-a-guide-for-business-leaders">estimates that it will take more than $27 trillion of capital spending through 2050</a> ($900 billion per year on average) to deploy US climate solutions at scale.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a06fa425-4242-461a-89be-f68c00be8ae7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a06fa425-4242-461a-89be-f68c00be8ae7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/navigating-americas-net-zero-frontier-a-guide-for-business-leaders">Navigating Americas net-zero frontier: A guide for business leaders</a>, McKinsey, May 5, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Several pieces of recent legislation include significant investments to make progress toward these aims. The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA)<a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-inflation-reduction-act-heres-whats-in-it"> directs nearly $400 billion in federal funding</a> to clean energy (see sidebar How the Inflation Reduction Act could unlock new net-zero opportunities for state agencies). And IRA funding promises to amplify the approximately $70 billion in clean-energy technology and demonstration projects funded under <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-us-bipartisan-infrastructure-law-breaking-it-down">the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL)</a>. Now is the time for states to consider how to access and use this financial support to achieve net-zero targets and advance an orderly energy transitionall while facilitating economic development (transitioning workforces, for example) and environmental equity (such as clean-energy benefits for disadvantaged communities). At the same time, while public funding can cover part of the transition, states may need to explore new financing mechanisms, as well as investments from public and private capital, to close investment gaps.</p>
<p>This article explores tactical steps state leaders can takeand four essential roles they can playto ensure their states meet net-zero goals efficiently and equitably while unlocking additional value. These actions could also help guide state, provincial, and other subnational leaders globally to ensure their net-zero transitions deliver for all.</p>
<h2>Three ways state leaders can jump-start the decarbonization journey</h2>
<p>Some states may already be off and running with their decarbonization plans. Others may be looking for a place to start. Based on our experience, we have identified three no regrets action areas that can help leaders initiate or accelerate their states plans.</p>
<h3>Understand the states current role in the energy transition</h3>
<p>In states that are in the early stages of decarbonization, leaders can consider several moves to gain a baseline understanding of the states current role in the energy transitionassessing both its carbon footprint and the potential for progress. States that are further along on their decarbonization journeys could still benefit from these actions, as ongoing factors (rapidly changing cost trajectories of emerging technologies, for example) may affect previous assessments.</p>
<!-- -->
<ul>
    <li><em>Create a comprehensive, quantified baseline of in-state emissions</em>. This assessment could include point-source<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a5174d5-93fe-4c64-b63a-0cbbf344bf04"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a5174d5-93fe-4c64-b63a-0cbbf344bf04" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Point-source emissions are generated by sources that are in a fixed location, such as large industrial facilities and power plants.</span></span></span></a></span> and sector-specific emissions. </li>
    <li><em>Set detailed transition targets and related policies</em>. States can build on any previously announced state-level emissions reduction targets and commitment timelines, as well as existing clean-energy plans and road maps to achieve targets, clean-energy incentive programs, publicprivate convening mechanisms, and company commitments. States can lead the way by setting targets to <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/target-net-zero-a-journey-to-decarbonizing-the-public-sector">decarbonize state-owned assets</a> such as buildings and vehicle fleets.</li>
    <li><em>Assess the resources that can help the state achieve net-zero </em>goals. These resources could include natural resources, physical infrastructure (such as existing electric power grid infrastructure that has supportive permitting to enable renewable integration), financial resources, skilled workers, and public support. In the process, leaders can also identify the potential resource gaps.</li>
    <li><em>Set metrics to monitor progressand get ahead of roadblocks</em>. Key metrics might include state-level emissions intensity, investment gaps, the percentage of clean-energy production, and impacts on <a href="/bem/our-insights/impacts-of-climate-change-on-black-populations-in-the-united-states">high-risk    communities</a>. Leaders can also ask, What might impede progress? Roadblocks could include scarce private capital in the clean-energy sector, lack of cost-effective solutions and investments, permitting, <a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/could-supply-chain-issues-derail-the-energy-transition">supply chain risks</a>, and lack of coordinated effort among stakeholders.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Develop or update decarbonization pathways around different scenarios</h3>
<p>Achieving net-zero goals in an orderly fashion could prove challenging and unpredictable, given ever-changing market conditions, shifts in energy costs (including potential <a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/a-balancing-act-securing-european-gas-and-power-markets">shocks</a>), emerging technologies, supply chain development, <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-economic-transformation-what-would-change-in-the-net-zero-transition">workforce availability</a>, and shifting policies. To get ahead of the <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-to-confront-uncertainty-in-your-strategy">uncertainty</a>, leaders can develop decarbonization pathways based on different scenarios with the following moves:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Factor reliability, resiliency, and affordability into any potential changes to the power system, from generation to the distribution grid</em>. As a starting point, leaders could use hourly supply-and-demand matching models to understand the states current energy system requirements. From there, they could analyze cleantech costs (with views on the optimal role of emerging technologies such as hydrogen and carbon capture, utilization, and storage) under various policy and economic scenarios. Its also important to anticipate market shifts. What could be the effects, for example, of a rapid acceleration of transportation and heating electrification? Or a decline in natural gas demand?</li>
    <li><em>Understand the different trajectories and pathways for climate technologies</em>. By 2050, about 90 percent of total global emissions can be reduced with existing climate technologies; however, many of these technologies are not currently cost competitive, and <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/what-would-it-take-to-scale-critical-climate-technologies">only 10 percent are considered commercially mature</a>.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="31dbc22c-e6c5-47e6-9742-5f9953507821"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="31dbc22c-e6c5-47e6-9742-5f9953507821" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/what-would-it-take-to-scale-critical-climate-technologies">What would it take to scale critical climate technologies?</a>, McKinsey, December 1, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Leaders can account for available and emerging technologies and the potential for scaling technologies in decarbonization scenarios, and they can factor in state-specific considerations such as existing power infrastructure and natural resources. </li>
    <li><em>Anticipate the potential effectsintended or notof implementing a decarbonization pathway</em>. Considerations could include cross-sector interactions, implementation costs, socioeconomic effects (environmental-justice concerns or workforce requirements, for example), and infrastructure requirements for key technologies, such as the degree to which a grid needs to be built out to support renewables and electrification. </li>
    <li><em>Create an action plan</em>. Once scenarios are identified, leaders will likely need to prioritize actions based on cost, feasibility, and abatement potential. A <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/net-zero-or-bust-beating-the-abatement-cost-curve-for-growth">marginal abatement cost curve, which compares emissions reduction potential and costs for a set of decarbonization solutions</a>, is one tool that states can use to assess a set of possible carbon abatement actions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="30b8df26-fdbe-4dc8-a145-b89ea38e82a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="30b8df26-fdbe-4dc8-a145-b89ea38e82a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more, see <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/net-zero-or-bust-beating-the-abatement-cost-curve-for-growth">Net zero or bust: Beating the abatement cost curve for growth</a>, McKinsey, April 13, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> This approach can help inform investment and policy decisions and identify the role private capital can play. A marginal abatement cost curve illustrating how the United States can stay on track to meet net-zero targets, for example, shows that investment in passenger electric vehicles (EVs) has relatively low-cost, high-carbon-abatement potential compared with investment in shipping and aviation decarbonization (Exhibit 1). At the state level, factors such as local industry, infrastructure, and energy mix could affect the potential value of abatement activities. (Later in the article, well explore how states can effectively create an integrated plan.)</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20us%20states%20can%20advance%20a%20successful%20clean%20energy%20transition/uscleanenergy-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Governments could use a marginal abatement cost curve to prioritize cost-effective decarbonization activities for public sector operations." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20us%20states%20can%20advance%20a%20successful%20clean%20energy%20transition/uscleanenergy-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Coordinate with stakeholders on what it will take to be successful</h3>
<ul>
    <li><em>Identify the new skills and capabilities that could accelerate the transition</em>. State leaders, for instance, may need to develop (or bring in)   expertise on power systems, distributed energy resources (solar, EVs, batteries), emissions modeling, economic and financial analyses, capital formation and investment strategy, workforce development, and overall operating model. </li>
    <li><em>Stay up to date on funding opportunities and climate technologies</em>. States could use federal tools and portals, such as the BIL maps dashboard<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7ef13451-f7c0-4929-82cf-1e4c31bdf625"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7ef13451-f7c0-4929-82cf-1e4c31bdf625" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Summary of the announced and awarded funding from the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law. </span></span></span></a></span> to help navigate funding possibilities. States could also use industry forums, such as the National Association of State Energy Officials, to stay current on developments in technology and best practices.</li>
    <li><em>Deploy resources efficiently</em>. To do this, states could establish a <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/delivering-on-the-promise-of-federal-infrastructure-funds-in-states">central delivery team</a> that can enable capability building, data-based performance tracking, and risk management across agencies and initiatives.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="39b5a70c-b2ad-4564-a8c4-a8f26d15c1fb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="39b5a70c-b2ad-4564-a8c4-a8f26d15c1fb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more, see Kate Luther, Asuquo Mfon, Sara Slayton ORourke, and Todd Wintner, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/delivering-on-the-promise-of-federal-infrastructure-funds-in-states">Delivering on the promise of federal infrastructure funds in states</a>, McKinsey, May 9, 2022. </span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<h2>Four key roles state leaders could play in the clean-energy transition</h2>
<p>State leaders have the authority to convene a wide array of stakeholders, from private investors to community organizers. They can ensure their states remain attractive places to do business while prioritizing socioeconomic considerations, such as job creation and directing resources to underserved communities. They bring greater levels of patience for financial returns and a higher tolerance for risk than private-sector participantsqualities that could prove crucial given the expense and time associated with building new energy infrastructure. </p>
<p>How leaders steward, organize, shape, and engage with stakeholders across the states energy ecosystem varies greatly across the country and will likely change dramatically in the coming years. Some states may advance most of their transition efforts directly through state energy offices and commissions. Others may lead through a broader framework of energy, economic development, and infrastructure-focused agencies. Policy toolssuch as permitting reforms, clean-energy manufacturing initiatives, and workforce reskilling programsas well as regulatory certainty and clear action plans, could all help advance the transition. </p>
<p>To meet the challenges of the clean-energy transition and unlock its many opportunities, state leaders could play four key roles: convenor, planner, coordinator, and catalyst. States that are further along on their energy transition journeys may assume all four roles, while those that are just embarking on it may choose to focus on feweror even just one.</p>
<h3>Convenor</h3>
<p>States can convene public and private sector stakeholdersincluding local communitiesto develop emissions abatement and energy transition pathways, while propelling economic development (see sidebar The characteristics of an effective convenor). States, for example, are already convening stakeholders to develop hubs for hydrogen or carbon capture, utilization, and storage. These hubs bring together hard-to-abate industries, cleantech companies, and communities that are looking to build shared infrastructure. At the time of this writing, about half of US states are leading or participating in the development of hydrogen hubs, which involves bringing together essential industry, community, and regional partners to create detailed, multisector project plans across production, transportation, and end uses.</p>
<p>Another example of convening stakeholders can be found in Belgium, where the Port of Antwerp-Bruges is leading a project to aid the regions transition to a circular and clean-energy economy. This includes developing a shared CO<sub>2</sub> transport-and-export facility with chemical and energy companies, with a potential CO<sub>2</sub> export capacity of up to 10 million metric tons per year (MTPA) by 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="21e3e0d2-7259-4594-8905-1346a6bde292"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="21e3e0d2-7259-4594-8905-1346a6bde292" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Air Liquide, Fluxys Belgium and Port of Antwerp-Bruges awarded EU funding for building the Antwerp@C CO<sub>2</sub> Export Hub, Air Liquide press release, December 12, 2022. </span></span></span></a></span></p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The characteristics of an effective convenor</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>States that have the following </strong>knowledge, attributes, and capabilities could be well positioned for a convenor role in the energy transition:</p>
<ul>
    <li>a holistic, comprehensive understanding of important stakeholders (public, private, and social) and their energy, economic, and environmental-equity needsto help ensure a diverse and relevant set of perspectives and trade-offs are considered as part of critical decision making </li>
    <li>long-standing, trusted relationships with public and private actors in the energy sector, to serve as a neutral party that can help broker relationships, make introductions, and facilitate coordination with stakeholders that may not have experience working together </li>
    <li>organizational structure (a steering committee or stakeholder engagement team, for example) and ability to conduct extensive stakeholder engagement activities and manage the wide range of relationships</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>State leaders could also use their convenor role to inform the planning and development of interstate and regional clean-energy transmission infrastructure. They could bring together renewable developers, utilities, transmission developers, engineering and construction companies, independent system operators, and municipalities to help identify regional infrastructure needs and, if theres an opportunity, facilitate delivery of renewables to neighboring states. This group of stakeholders could also explore broader implications for economic development and environmental equity. In 2019, for instance, Maine launched the Maine Offshore Wind Initiative, which brings together neighboring states and federal participants to assess the opportunity for offshore wind energy development in the Gulf of Maine, the level of investment required, and the implications for economic development.</p>
<h3>Planner</h3>
<p>In addition to convening stakeholders, state leaders can develop an integrated plan that sets an overall direction for the states clean-energy transition. Such a plan could rely on inputs from energy providers, community leaders, and other key actors across the state and surrounding regions and inform critical decisions down the line (see sidebar The characteristics of an effective planner). An integrated plan could include granular forecasts for power demand and distributed energy resources (such as behind the meter<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2e71ed2d-e54b-434e-b1d8-971ab90872eb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2e71ed2d-e54b-434e-b1d8-971ab90872eb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Behind the meter refers to energy resources that are not directly integrated into the electric power system. </span></span></span></a></span> generation, EV assets, and storage), to account for an evolving power mix while ensuring  the grid is still reliable (Exhibit 2). Such demand and capacity projections can help leaders anticipate how resources and planned activities might evolve.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20us%20states%20can%20advance%20a%20successful%20clean%20energy%20transition/uscleanenergy-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="For energy transition plans, states can project energy demand for the power mix under different scenarios. " src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20us%20states%20can%20advance%20a%20successful%20clean%20energy%20transition/uscleanenergy-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>To support equity and resilience, state leaders can establish environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria in planning for climate-resilient infrastructure, which may be costlier but better protect lives and livelihoods. States, for example, could identify climate-vulnerable regions and work with communities to build power distribution lines underground, to help prevent power outages at hospitals and schools. </p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The characteristics of an effective planner</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>States that have the following </strong>knowledge, attributes, and capabilities could be well positioned for a planner role in the energy transition:</p>
<ul>
    <li>an understanding of the utility infrastructure planning process, as well as standards to identify collaboration opportunities</li>
    <li>long-standing, trusted relationships with cleantech developers, utilities, and regulators </li>
    <li>a comprehensive understanding of climate technologies (hydrogen; carbon capture, utilization, and storage; electric vehicles; and clean power), as well as the ability to recognize cost and implementation considerations, including project lead times, carbon abatement potential, and power reliability</li>
    <li>an ability to quantify the economic impact of investments on economic output (GDP), jobs, and emissions reductions</li>
    <li>power system and energy modeling capabilities, particularly at the distribution and behind the meter levels<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="552facaa-fbdb-45d9-8cc2-064562781cbc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="552facaa-fbdb-45d9-8cc2-064562781cbc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Behind the meter refers to energy resources that are not directly integrated into the electric power system.</span></span></span></a></span> </li>
    <li>a thorough understanding of how to navigate and secure federal clean-energy funding through the <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-chips-and-science-act-heres-whats-in-it">Creating Helpful Incentives to Produce Semiconductors and Science (CHIPS) Act</a>, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/navigating-the-complexity-of-the-bipartisan-infrastructure-law">Bipartisan Infrastructure Law</a> (BIL), and the <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-inflation-reduction-act-heres-whats-in-it">Inflation Reduction Act</a> (IRA), as well as other financing opportunities</li>
    <li>an ability to efficiently track all energy-related activities and updates on funding opportunities at the local and regional levels</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>New York State recently developed and approved a road map for the Climate Leadership and Community Protection Act (CLCPA).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="39c0225a-a1cb-4969-8807-11530c49ccbe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="39c0225a-a1cb-4969-8807-11530c49ccbe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>New York State Climate Action Council Scoping Plan</em>, December 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> This road map to meet policy objectives includes a range of considerations, including state-level greenhouse gas emissions scenarios, investments in energy efficiencies, EV adoption, and sector-level decarbonization strategies with provisions to support equity. The original bill ensures that at least 35 percent of spending on clean energy and energy efficiency programs goes to disadvantaged communities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="35293960-ca16-40cf-a4c2-63204279724b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="35293960-ca16-40cf-a4c2-63204279724b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">New York State Climate Action Council finalizes scoping plan to advance nation-leading climate law, NYSERDA press release, December 19, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In New Zealand, the Taranaki regions economic development agency, Venture Taranaki, convened community and business stakeholders to develop equitable clean-energy transition pathways and coordinate financing opportunities.</p>
<p>Integrated energy planning can also bring together small and resource-strained communities to assess their energy requirements and identify potential regional synergies. The Western States Rural Transportation Consortium, for instance, is developing projects to address rural-transportation issues across five US states.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0beeaf2f-15aa-4421-8808-b35c6febcf2d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0beeaf2f-15aa-4421-8808-b35c6febcf2d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The Western States Rural Transportation Consortium is a partnership between the Departments of Transportation for California, Nevada, Oregon, Utah, and Washington.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Coordinator</h3>
<p>Infrastructure projects, especially those that are first of a kind, are facing rising capital costs and interest rates. To help ensure projects are executed efficiently, leaders can coordinate with state and federal agencies when planning and siting interstate energy infrastructure, to streamline permitting and reduce development lead times (see sidebar The characteristics of an effective coordinator).</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The characteristics of an effective coordinator</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>States that have the following</strong> knowledge, attributes, and capabilities could be well positioned for a coordinator role in the energy transition:</p>
<ul>
    <li>long-standing, trusted relationships across infrastructure segments (energy, water, broadband, transport), state departments of economic development and sustainability, and applicable federal agencies </li>
    <li>seen as an honest broker among collaborating agencies, enabling effective partnerships</li>
    <li>an understanding of the infrastructure development, real estate, and land use planning process and opportunities for coordination across the relevant agencies</li>
    <li>an ability to engage early with important stakeholders on projects to identify potential areas of overlap and the possibility of <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/dig-once-could-help-states-manage-material-and-worker-shortages">dig-once approaches</a></li>
    <li>a platform or forum to enhance coordination and communications across stakeholders, such as a standing working session or portal</li>
    <li>a comprehensive view of all federal funding opportunities agencies have or will apply for and when projects will launch</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Limited access to grid capacity and long permitting timelines, especially for power transmission lines, are significant barriers to implementing clean-energy projects, for example.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f19dd6bb-d18d-4d01-b674-b199ce6be38b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f19dd6bb-d18d-4d01-b674-b199ce6be38b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">David Gelles, The U.S. will need thousands of wind farms. Will small towns go along?, <em>New York Times</em>, December 30, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> When planning and siting transmission lines, state leaders can work with transportation and land use departments, as well as utilities, to identify existing rights-of-way and assess multiuse corridors to shrink project lead times. New Yorks CLCPA streamlined a complex transmission permitting process into a single permitting office and put processes in place to allocate costs across key stakeholders.</p>
<p>State leaders can also work with transportation departments and utilities to plan and site <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/building-the-electric-vehicle-charging-infrastructure-america-needs">EV infrastructure</a>, to ensure there is sufficient grid capacity to accommodate potential demand growth and mitigate risks. Through the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure (NEVI) Formula Program, states coordinate and submit EV infrastructure deployment plans that involve utilities as well as state agencies overseeing energy, climate, natural resources and environmental management, economic development, and transportation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f8b8f82e-7abf-4193-912f-8140fd3acf0b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f8b8f82e-7abf-4193-912f-8140fd3acf0b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Historic step: All fifty states plus D.C. and Puerto Rico greenlit to move EV charging networks forward, covering 75,000 miles of highway, US Department of Transportation news release, September 27, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Catalyst</h3>
<p>States are uniquely positioned to <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/climate-tech-competitiveness-can-the-united-states-raise-its-game">catalyze the development, adoption, and scaling of climate technologies</a> (see sidebar The characteristics of an effective catalyst). High up-front capital costs and uncertain demand for new climate technologies may give the private sector pause when it comes to investing in clean-energy infrastructure. However, states could potentially boost private investment by leading on public financing and exploring publicprivate partnerships </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The characteristics of an effective catalyst</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>States that have the following</strong> knowledge, attributes, and capabilities could be well positioned for a catalyst role in the energy transition:</p>
<ul>
    <li>dedicated budget and funding programs to finance regional and local decarbonization and climate-related activities</li>
    <li>a comprehensive fact base that informs investment decisions on cleantech commercialization and rural energy transition projects</li>
    <li>organizational structure and capacity to attract private capital and reduce project risks, possibly including what it would take to build publicprivate partnerships, how to make a major project bankable, and how to strategically invest in projects, infrastructure, and capability-building programs to accelerate decarbonization</li>
    <li>an ability to spark enthusiasm among potential stakeholders to propel emotional investment and action</li>
    <li>an understanding of the full suite of funding and financing mechanisms that are available</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>States, for instance, could help jump-start the creation of hydrogen hubs through public financing that improves the economics for private investment and generates broader socioeconomic benefits for communities in the form of jobs. The White House and the Department of Energy recently announced the selection of seven regional clean-hydrogen hubs that are eligible to receive $7 billion in funding from the BIL.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f39be9fe-ab38-42e6-8d7b-74c04aeb0ced"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f39be9fe-ab38-42e6-8d7b-74c04aeb0ced" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Biden-Harris administration announces regional clean hydrogen hubs to drive clean manufacturing and jobs, White House news release, October 13, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Over the last decade, Connecticut Green Bank successfully mobilized nearly $2 billion of private capital via $322 million in public financing through low-interest loans and bond programs for solar installation and energy efficiency projects.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="71325783-8755-4d15-ba85-bea6df92d40a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="71325783-8755-4d15-ba85-bea6df92d40a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Connecticut Green Bank Annual Report 2022.</em></span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>States could also consider using subsidies to help offset clean-energy transition costs for lower-income communities and launch programs to ensure no one is left behind, particularly in communities that may be economically affected by the transition. Port Esbjerg, a municipal-owned port authority in Denmark that is highly dependent on offshore oil and gas, for example, has developed initiatives to reskill workers in renewables and related industries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="88af63dc-f141-4d2b-aa14-6da9af88fd6a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="88af63dc-f141-4d2b-aa14-6da9af88fd6a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">New offshore training programme to ensure the right skill sets for offshore wind adventure, Port Esbjerg news release, December 18, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<hr>
<p>Achieving a successful and equitable clean-energy transition in the United States will require a coordinated effort. By initiating and accelerating state-level decarbonizationand playing one or more of four essential rolesstate leaders can help scale climate technologies, achieve net-zero objectives, and ensure the nation and planet benefit.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/adam-barth">Adam Barth</a></strong> is a partner in McKinseys Houston office, <strong>Karina Gerstenschlager </strong>is a consultant in the Denver office, <strong>Ksenia Kaladiouk</strong> is a partner in the Boston office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/adi-kumar">Adi Kumar</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Washington, DC, office. </p>
<p>This article represents views from the McKinsey Center for Government. </p>

targets."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-01-29T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAs the United States \u003c/strong\u003emoves toward decarbonization, states and their leaders will help determine whether net zero is achieved\u0026mdash;and whether the energy transition elevates communities to deliver a more prosperous future for all. Last year, we outlined \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/toward-a-more-orderly-us-energy-transition-six-key-action-areas\"\u003esix critical action areas\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that could enable a more orderly transition, from designing a capital-efficient and affordable energy system to accelerating technological innovation to ensure timely deployment of new clean technologies.[[Footnote 1]] Across these areas, states have an opportunity to advance the transition, improve energy affordability, and support inclusive economic growth. Traditionally, states have influenced the creation of new sources of energy through formal policies, regulatory constructs, and planning and permitting authorities. But the national energy landscape is undergoing tectonic shifts. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/navigating-americas-net-zero-frontier-a-guide-for-business-leaders\"\u003eestimates that it will take more than $27 trillion of capital spending through 2050\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;($900 billion per year on average) to deploy US climate solutions at scale.[[Footnote 2]] Several pieces of recent legislation include significant investments to make progress toward these aims. The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA)\u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-inflation-reduction-act-heres-whats-in-it\"\u003e directs nearly $400 billion in federal funding\u003c/a\u003e to clean energy (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;How the Inflation Reduction Act could unlock new net-zero opportunities for state agencies\u0026rdquo;). And IRA funding promises to amplify the approximately $70 billion in clean-energy technology and demonstration projects funded under \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-us-bipartisan-infrastructure-law-breaking-it-down\"\u003ethe Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL)\u003c/a\u003e. Now is the time for states to consider how to access and use this financial support to achieve net-zero targets and advance an orderly energy transition\u0026mdash;all while facilitating economic development (transitioning workforces, for example) and environmental equity (such as clean-energy benefits for disadvantaged communities). At the same time, while public funding can cover part of the transition, states may need to explore new financing mechanisms, as well as investments from public and private capital, to close investment gaps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article explores tactical steps state leaders can take\u0026mdash;and four essential roles they can play\u0026mdash;to ensure their states meet net-zero goals efficiently and equitably while unlocking additional value. These actions could also help guide state, provincial, and other subnational leaders globally to ensure their net-zero transitions deliver for all.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThree ways state leaders can jump-start the decarbonization journey\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome states may already be off and running with their decarbonization plans. Others may be looking for a place to start. Based on our experience, we have identified three \u0026ldquo;no regrets\u0026rdquo; action areas that can help leaders initiate or accelerate their states\u0026rsquo; plans.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUnderstand the state\u0026rsquo;s current role in the energy transition\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn states that are in the early stages of decarbonization, leaders can consider several moves to gain a baseline understanding of the state\u0026rsquo;s current role in the energy transition\u0026mdash;assessing both its carbon footprint and the potential for progress. States that are further along on their decarbonization journeys could still benefit from these actions, as ongoing factors (rapidly changing cost trajectories of emerging technologies, for example) may affect previous assessments.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCreate a comprehensive, quantified baseline of in-state emissions\u003c/em\u003e. This assessment could include point-source[[Footnote 3]] and sector-specific emissions. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSet detailed transition targets and related policies\u003c/em\u003e. States can build on any previously announced state-level emissions reduction targets and commitment timelines, as well as existing clean-energy plans and road maps to achieve targets, clean-energy incentive programs, public\u0026ndash;private convening mechanisms, and company commitments. States can lead the way by setting targets to \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/target-net-zero-a-journey-to-decarbonizing-the-public-sector\"\u003edecarbonize state-owned assets\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;such as buildings and vehicle fleets.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAssess the resources that can help the state achieve net-zero \u003c/em\u003egoals. These resources could include natural resources, physical infrastructure (such as existing electric power grid infrastructure that has supportive permitting to enable renewable integration), financial resources, skilled workers, and public support. In the process, leaders can also identify the potential resource gaps.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSet metrics to monitor progress\u0026mdash;and get ahead of roadblocks\u003c/em\u003e. Key metrics might include state-level emissions intensity, investment gaps, the percentage of clean-energy production, and impacts on \u003ca href=\"/bem/our-insights/impacts-of-climate-change-on-black-populations-in-the-united-states\"\u003ehigh-risk    communities\u003c/a\u003e. Leaders can also ask, \u0026ldquo;What might impede progress?\u0026rdquo; Roadblocks could include scarce private capital in the clean-energy sector, lack of cost-effective solutions and investments, permitting, \u003ca href=\"/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/could-supply-chain-issues-derail-the-energy-transition\"\u003esupply chain risks\u003c/a\u003e, and lack of coordinated effort among stakeholders.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDevelop or update decarbonization pathways around different scenarios\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAchieving net-zero goals in an orderly fashion could prove challenging and unpredictable, given ever-changing market conditions, shifts in energy costs (including potential \u003ca href=\"/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/a-balancing-act-securing-european-gas-and-power-markets\"\u003e\u0026ldquo;shocks\u0026rdquo;\u003c/a\u003e), emerging technologies, supply chain development, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-economic-transformation-what-would-change-in-the-net-zero-transition\"\u003eworkforce availability\u003c/a\u003e, and shifting policies. To get ahead of the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-to-confront-uncertainty-in-your-strategy\"\u003euncertainty\u003c/a\u003e, leaders can develop decarbonization pathways based on different scenarios with the following moves:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFactor reliability, resiliency, and affordability into any potential changes to the power system, from generation to the distribution grid\u003c/em\u003e. As a starting point, leaders could use hourly supply-and-demand matching models to understand the state\u0026rsquo;s current energy system requirements. From there, they could analyze cleantech costs (with views on the optimal role of emerging technologies such as hydrogen and carbon capture, utilization, and storage) under various policy and economic scenarios. It\u0026rsquo;s also important to anticipate market shifts. What could be the effects, for example, of a rapid acceleration of transportation and heating electrification? Or a decline in natural gas demand?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnderstand the different trajectories and pathways for climate technologies\u003c/em\u003e. By 2050, about 90 percent of total global emissions can be reduced with existing climate technologies; however, many of these technologies are not currently cost competitive, and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/what-would-it-take-to-scale-critical-climate-technologies\"\u003eonly 10 percent are considered commercially mature\u003c/a\u003e.[[Footnote 4]] Leaders can account for available and emerging technologies and the potential for scaling technologies in decarbonization scenarios, and they can factor in state-specific considerations such as existing power infrastructure and natural resources. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAnticipate the potential effects\u0026mdash;intended or not\u0026mdash;of implementing a decarbonization pathway\u003c/em\u003e. Considerations could include cross-sector interactions, implementation costs, socioeconomic effects (environmental-justice concerns or workforce requirements, for example), and infrastructure requirements for key technologies, such as the degree to which a grid needs to be built out to support renewables and electrification. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCreate an action plan\u003c/em\u003e. Once scenarios are identified, leaders will likely need to prioritize actions based on cost, feasibility, and abatement potential. A \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/net-zero-or-bust-beating-the-abatement-cost-curve-for-growth\"\u003emarginal abatement cost curve, which compares emissions reduction potential and costs for a set of decarbonization solutions\u003c/a\u003e, is one tool that states can use to assess a set of possible carbon abatement actions.[[Footnote 5]] This approach can help inform investment and policy decisions and identify the role private capital can play. A marginal abatement cost curve illustrating how the United States can stay on track to meet net-zero targets, for example, shows that investment in passenger electric vehicles (EVs) has relatively low-cost, high-carbon-abatement potential compared with investment in shipping and aviation decarbonization (Exhibit 1). At the state level, factors such as local industry, infrastructure, and energy mix could affect the potential value of abatement activities. (Later in the article, we\u0026rsquo;ll explore how states can effectively create an integrated plan.)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch3\u003eCoordinate with stakeholders on what it will take to be successful\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIdentify the new skills and capabilities that could accelerate the transition\u003c/em\u003e. State leaders, for instance, may need to develop (or bring in)   expertise on power systems, distributed energy resources (solar, EVs, batteries), emissions modeling, economic and financial analyses, capital formation and investment strategy, workforce development, and overall operating model. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eStay up to date on funding opportunities and climate technologies\u003c/em\u003e. States could use federal tools and portals, such as the BIL maps dashboard[[Footnote 6]] to help navigate funding possibilities. States could also use industry forums, such as the National Association of State Energy Officials, to stay current on developments in technology and best practices.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDeploy resources efficiently\u003c/em\u003e. To do this, states could establish a \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/delivering-on-the-promise-of-federal-infrastructure-funds-in-states\"\u003ecentral delivery team\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that can enable capability building, data-based performance tracking, and risk management across agencies and initiatives.[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFour key roles state leaders could play in the clean-energy transition\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eState leaders have the authority to convene a wide array of stakeholders, from private investors to community organizers. They can ensure their states remain attractive places to do business while prioritizing socioeconomic considerations, such as job creation and directing resources to underserved communities. They bring greater levels of patience for financial returns and a higher tolerance for risk than private-sector participants\u0026mdash;qualities that could prove crucial given the expense and time associated with building new energy infrastructure. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHow leaders steward, organize, shape, and engage with stakeholders across the state\u0026rsquo;s energy ecosystem varies greatly across the country and will likely change dramatically in the coming years. Some states may advance most of their transition efforts directly through state energy offices and commissions. Others may lead through a broader framework of energy, economic development, and infrastructure-focused agencies. Policy tools\u0026mdash;such as permitting reforms, clean-energy manufacturing initiatives, and workforce reskilling programs\u0026mdash;as well as regulatory certainty and clear action plans, could all help advance the transition. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo meet the challenges of the clean-energy transition and unlock its many opportunities, state leaders could play four key roles: convenor, planner, coordinator, and catalyst. States that are further along on their energy transition journeys may assume all four roles, while those that are just embarking on it may choose to focus on fewer\u0026mdash;or even just one.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eConvenor\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStates can convene public and private sector stakeholders\u0026mdash;including local communities\u0026mdash;to develop emissions abatement and energy transition pathways, while propelling economic development (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The characteristics of an effective convenor\u0026rdquo;). States, for example, are already convening stakeholders to develop hubs for hydrogen or carbon capture, utilization, and storage. These hubs bring together hard-to-abate industries, cleantech companies, and communities that are looking to build shared infrastructure. At the time of this writing, about half of US states are leading or participating in the development of hydrogen hubs, which involves bringing together essential industry, community, and regional partners to create detailed, multisector project plans across production, transportation, and end uses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother example of convening stakeholders can be found in Belgium, where the Port of Antwerp-Bruges is leading a project to aid the region\u0026rsquo;s transition to a circular and clean-energy economy. This includes developing a shared CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e transport-and-export facility with chemical and energy companies, with a potential CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e export capacity of up to 10 million metric tons per year (MTPA) by 2030.[[Footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eState leaders could also use their convenor role to inform the planning and development of interstate and regional clean-energy transmission infrastructure. They could bring together renewable developers, utilities, transmission developers, engineering and construction companies, independent system operators, and municipalities to help identify regional infrastructure needs and, if there\u0026rsquo;s an opportunity, facilitate delivery of renewables to neighboring states. This group of stakeholders could also explore broader implications for economic development and environmental equity. In 2019, for instance, Maine launched the Maine Offshore Wind Initiative, which brings together neighboring states and federal participants to assess the opportunity for offshore wind energy development in the Gulf of Maine, the level of investment required, and the implications for economic development.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePlanner\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to convening stakeholders, state leaders can develop an integrated plan that sets an overall direction for the state\u0026rsquo;s clean-energy transition. Such a plan could rely on inputs from energy providers, community leaders, and other key actors across the state and surrounding regions and inform critical decisions down the line (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The characteristics of an effective planner\u0026rdquo;). An integrated plan could include granular forecasts for power demand and distributed energy resources (such as \u0026ldquo;behind the meter\u0026rdquo;[[Footnote 9]] generation, EV assets, and storage), to account for an evolving power mix while ensuring  the grid is still reliable (Exhibit 2). Such demand and capacity projections can help leaders anticipate how resources and planned activities might evolve.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo support equity and resilience, state leaders can establish environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria in planning for climate-resilient infrastructure, which may be costlier but better protect lives and livelihoods. States, for example, could identify climate-vulnerable regions and work with communities to build power distribution lines underground, to help prevent power outages at hospitals and schools. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eNew York State recently developed and approved a road map for the Climate Leadership and Community Protection Act (CLCPA).[[Footnote 10]] This road map to meet policy objectives includes a range of considerations, including state-level greenhouse gas emissions scenarios, investments in energy efficiencies, EV adoption, and sector-level decarbonization strategies with provisions to support equity. The original bill ensures that at least 35 percent of spending on clean energy and energy efficiency programs goes to disadvantaged communities.[[Footnote 11]] In New Zealand, the Taranaki region\u0026rsquo;s economic development agency, Venture Taranaki, convened community and business stakeholders to develop equitable clean-energy transition pathways and coordinate financing opportunities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrated energy planning can also bring together small and resource-strained communities to assess their energy requirements and identify potential regional synergies. The Western States Rural Transportation Consortium, for instance, is developing projects to address rural-transportation issues across five US states.[[Footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCoordinator\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInfrastructure projects, especially those that are \u0026ldquo;first of a kind,\u0026rdquo; are facing rising capital costs and interest rates. To help ensure projects are executed efficiently, leaders can coordinate with state and federal agencies when planning and siting interstate energy infrastructure, to streamline permitting and reduce development lead times (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The characteristics of an effective coordinator\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eLimited access to grid capacity and long permitting timelines, especially for power transmission lines, are significant barriers to implementing clean-energy projects, for example.[[Footnote 13]] When planning and siting transmission lines, state leaders can work with transportation and land use departments, as well as utilities, to identify existing rights-of-way and assess multiuse corridors to shrink project lead times. New York\u0026rsquo;s CLCPA streamlined a complex transmission permitting process into a single permitting office and put processes in place to allocate costs across key stakeholders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eState leaders can also work with transportation departments and utilities to plan and site \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/building-the-electric-vehicle-charging-infrastructure-america-needs\"\u003eEV infrastructure\u003c/a\u003e, to ensure there is sufficient grid capacity to accommodate potential demand growth and mitigate risks. Through the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure (NEVI) Formula Program, states coordinate and submit EV infrastructure deployment plans that involve utilities as well as state agencies overseeing energy, climate, natural resources and environmental management, economic development, and transportation.[[Footnote 14]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCatalyst\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStates are uniquely positioned to \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/climate-tech-competitiveness-can-the-united-states-raise-its-game\"\u003ecatalyze the development, adoption, and scaling of climate technologies\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The characteristics of an effective catalyst\u0026rdquo;). High up-front capital costs and uncertain demand for new climate technologies may give the private sector pause when it comes to investing in clean-energy infrastructure. However, states could potentially boost private investment by leading on public financing and exploring public\u0026ndash;private partnerships \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eStates, for instance, could help jump-start the creation of hydrogen hubs through public financing that improves the economics for private investment and generates broader socioeconomic benefits for communities in the form of jobs. The White House and the Department of Energy recently announced the selection of seven regional clean-hydrogen hubs that are eligible to receive $7 billion in funding from the BIL.[[Footnote 15]] Over the last decade, Connecticut Green Bank successfully mobilized nearly $2 billion of private capital via $322 million in public financing through low-interest loans and bond programs for solar installation and energy efficiency projects.[[Footnote 16]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStates could also consider using subsidies to help offset clean-energy transition costs for lower-income communities and launch programs to ensure no one is left behind, particularly in communities that may be economically affected by the transition. Port Esbjerg, a municipal-owned port authority in Denmark that is highly dependent on offshore oil and gas, for example, has developed initiatives to reskill workers in renewables and related industries.[[Footnote 17]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAchieving a successful and equitable clean-energy transition in the United States will require a coordinated effort. By initiating and accelerating state-level decarbonization\u0026mdash;and playing one or more of four essential roles\u0026mdash;state leaders can help scale climate technologies, achieve net-zero objectives, and ensure the nation and planet benefit.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":false},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-01-29T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor more, see \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/toward-a-more-orderly-us-energy-transition-six-key-action-areas\"\u003eToward a more orderly US energy transition: Six key action areas\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;
